contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=July 2009}} In [[combinatorial game theory]], a game is '''partisan''' if it is not [[impartial game|impartial]]. That is, some moves are available to one player and not to the other. Most games are partisan; for example, in [[chess]], only one player can move the white pieces. Partisan games are more difficult to analyze than [[impartial game]]s, as the [[Spragueâ€“Grundy theorem]] does not apply. However, the application of combinatorial game theory to partisan games allows the significance of ''numbers as games'' to be seen, in a way that is not possible with impartial games. {{DEFAULTSORT:Partisan Game}} [[Category:Combinatorial game theory]] {{Mathapplied-stub}}
